title.narrative: EQUITY AND INCLUSION IN PRIMARY SCHOOL

description.narrative: Inclusive strategies with a focus on girls and children with disabilities are strengthened at primary school level, which contributes to Equitable Access To Quality Education, Equity â€“ Focus On Girls' And Inclusive Education. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Advocacy And Public Engagement, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: Improved learning outcomes and equitable and inclusive education

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: Inclusive strategies with a focus on girls and children with disabilities are strengthened at primary school level

description.narrative: A safe school environment was assured through distribution of a code of conduct for teachers. promotion of clubs for girls' empowerment, and building teacher skills for children with special needs. | Status:On-track | As-of Date:04/08/2016

title.narrative: % or target primary schools in UNICEF supported districts with access to adequate teachers guides and pupils life skills learning materials
Status of districts implemeting school re-entry guidelines for pregnant girls as stated in the ETP.

baseline.value: Education and Training Policy (ETP) does not reflect school re-entry of pregnant school girls.

actual.value: 2016:Guidelines on Re-entry of pregnant girls to school has been finalised.% of schools indicating that they are implementing the guidelines:Mbeya = 16%Iringa = 16.7 %Njombe = 23.8%

title.narrative: % of teachers in UN-supported regions trained in gender responsive Pedagogy, modes of violence prevention and teachers' code of conduct
% of teachers trained that demonstrate minimum knowledge of Gender Responsive Pedagogy,modes of violence prevention and teachers' code of conduct

actual.value: 2016:Data not available but interviews with teachers indicate new positive practices, such as responding to needs of boys and girls in and outside of classrooms and alternative forms of discipline.

title.narrative: % of schools in UNICEF-supported regions with TUSEME clubs (better health clubs in ZNZ).
% Guidance and Counselling teachers trained on violence/HIV prevention and reporting and referral mechanisms for violence, abuse, neglect and exploitation cases
